title: Write VISION.md
description:
## Required Reading
- .claude/rules/vision-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Bootstrap description in .claude/commands/bootstrap.md

## Files to Create
- docs/VISION.md

## Requirements

Write VISION.md per vision-format rule.

Cobbler is a partial recursive component and a testbed for creating recursive behavior from guided coding agents. It applies the autogenic systems pattern to software development.

Coding agents (Claude, etc.) are guided components. They have self-programming capabilities - they can generate code and docs - but they work best with human oversight. They can run unguided, but the results may not be good. Left to work on a large task, a coding agent wastes tokens on orientation, iterates through misunderstandings, and produces inconsistent results.

Cobbler tests whether you can compose guided coding agents into a system that approaches recursive behavior. The hypothesis: if you break work into small enough pieces, prepare the right context for each piece, dispatch agents one-shot, and reflect on the results, the composed system behaves more like a recursive component than any individual guided agent could.

This is the research question at the heart of cobbler: can work breakdown + dispatch + self-reflection turn guided parts into a recursive whole?

Cobbler implements four autogenic self-* capabilities:

1. Self-orienting (cobbler measure): the system generates new objectives rather than only selecting from predefined goals. Measure analyzes project state and proposes new tasks - it creates objectives, not just picks from a backlog.

2. Self-programming (cobbler stitch): the system synthesizes new behaviors autonomously. Stitch dispatches a guided coding agent with a small, well-defined task and complete context. One-shot, no iteration. The agent synthesizes docs or code.

3. Self-reflection (cobbler inspect / cobbler mend): the system evaluates its own reasoning processes and decision frameworks. Inspect and mend evaluate what was produced, examine whether the right checks exist, and dispatch agents to fix issues.

4. Self-architecting (cobbler pattern): the system modifies its core architecture and integrates new functionality at runtime. Pattern proposes changes to ARCHITECTURE, PRDs, interfaces, and component organization.

The command set uses shoemaking metaphors:

| Self-capability | Command | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Generate objectives from project state |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Dispatch guided agent to synthesize docs/code |
| Self-reflection | cobbler inspect / mend | Evaluate output, dispatch agent to fix |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Propose structural and design changes |

Agents are plug-and-play. Cobbler defines an agent interface; any LLM backend can be swapped in. Different agents may be better at different tasks - a coding agent codes, a planning agent plans. Cobbler decides what to hand each agent.

Cobbler replaces prototype bash scripts (scripts/make-work.sh and scripts/do-work.sh) with a proper Go tool.

Sections to write:
1. Executive Summary: cobbler is a partial recursive component and testbed for composing guided coding agents into recursive behavior. Applies autogenic systems pattern to software development. Not an agent itself - a dispatch layer that breaks work down and composes guided agents. Not a task tracker, IDE plugin, or CI system.
2. Introduction: context (coding agents are guided components with self-programming capabilities, but waste tokens and produce inconsistent results on large tasks). Problem (guided agents alone do not achieve recursive behavior; large tasks cause iteration, token waste, and poor results). What cobbler does (tests whether work breakdown + one-shot dispatch + self-reflection can compose guided agents into recursive behavior). Introduce autogenic systems and the four self-* capabilities.
3. Why this project: testbed for the guided-to-recursive composition question. Token efficiency through work breakdown. Plug-and-play agent swapping. Graduates prototype scripts. Fills gap between task storage (crumbs) and agent execution.
4. Planning and Implementation: success criteria (guided agents complete tasks without iteration; composed system shows recursive properties - generates objectives, synthesizes behaviors, evaluates reasoning, modifies structure), phases table (01.0 stitch docs, 02.0 stitch code, 03.0 measure, 04.0 inspect/mend/pattern), risks table.
5. What This Is NOT: not a coding agent. Not a planning agent. Not a recursive component yet (partial - testbed). Not a task tracker (use crumbs). Not an IDE plugin. Not a CI system. Not an interactive agent session.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per vision-format present
- [ ] Clear that cobbler is a partial recursive component and testbed
- [ ] Clear that coding agents are guided components
- [ ] Research question stated: can work breakdown + dispatch + reflection compose guided agents into recursive behavior
- [ ] Formal self-* definitions used
- [ ] Work breakdown as token efficiency mechanism
- [ ] Plug-and-play agent swapping described
- [ ] Command mapping to self-* capabilities
- [ ] Origin story: replaces prototype scripts
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards
- [ ] File saved as docs/VISION.md

title: Write ARCHITECTURE.md
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/architecture-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Crumbs docs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (cupboard/table interfaces)
- Crumbs PRDs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/product-requirements/ (interface contracts)

## Files to Create
- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

## Requirements

Write ARCHITECTURE.md per architecture-format rule.

Cobbler is a partial recursive component that composes guided coding agents. The architecture must show how guided agents (which have self-programming but need oversight) are composed through work breakdown, one-shot dispatch, and self-reflection into a system that approaches recursive behavior.

The component hierarchy:
- Coding agents (Claude, etc.) = guided components with self-programming. They generate code and docs but work best with human oversight. Unguided results may be poor.
- Cobbler = partial recursive component. It does not execute work itself. It breaks work into small chunks, prepares context, dispatches guided agents one-shot, and reflects on results. The composition of these steps is what creates recursive-like behavior.

Autogenic self-* capabilities and their architectural realization:

1. Self-orienting (cobbler measure): generates new objectives by analyzing project state. Not selecting from a backlog - creating objectives. Replaces make-work.sh.

2. Self-programming (cobbler stitch): dispatches a guided coding agent with a small, well-defined task. One-shot, no iteration. Agent receives complete context and returns result. Replaces do-work.sh.

3. Self-reflection (cobbler inspect / cobbler mend): evaluates output and reasoning. Examines not just whether tests pass but whether the right tests exist. Dispatches agent to fix issues.

4. Self-architecting (cobbler pattern): dispatches agent to propose changes to ARCHITECTURE, PRDs, interfaces, component organization.

Commands:

| Self-capability | Command | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Generate objectives from project state |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Dispatch guided agent one-shot |
| Self-reflection | cobbler inspect / mend | Evaluate output, dispatch fix |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Propose structural changes |

Sections to write:
1. System Overview: cobbler is a partial recursive component that composes guided coding agents. It sits between crumbs cupboard and pluggable guided agents. The composition (work breakdown + one-shot dispatch + reflection) is what creates recursive-like behavior from guided parts. Lifecycle (ready -> claimed -> context gathered -> prompt built -> guided agent dispatched one-shot -> result -> quality gate -> closed). Pull-based coordination.
2. Main interfaces: Cupboard integration (import crumbs Go module, Cupboard.GetTable(name).Get/Set), Agent interface (the plug-and-play boundary; guided agents implement this; one-shot execution model), Executor interface (claim, gather context, build prompt, dispatch one-shot, evaluate, close). The agent interface abstracts over guided coding agents so different backends can be swapped in.
3. System Components: CLI (cobra, commands: measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern), Config (viper), Measure (self-orienting: generates objectives from project analysis - replaces make-work.sh), Stitch/Executor (self-programming: prepares context, dispatches guided agent one-shot - replaces do-work.sh), Inspect/Mend (self-reflection: evaluates output, dispatches fix), Pattern (self-architecting: proposes structural changes), Agent (abstraction over guided coding agents; Claude impl via anthropic-sdk-go; plug-and-play), Prompt Builder (templates for one-shot dispatch - gives guided agent everything it needs without iteration), Crumbs Client (thin wrapper around crumbs Go module).
4. Design Decisions: (a) cobbler is a partial recursive component composed from guided agents - the composition is the experiment, (b) work breakdown is how guided agents become useful without iteration - small tasks avoid the token waste and poor results of large tasks, (c) one-shot dispatch - no conversation with the agent, (d) agent interface abstracts over guided coding agents - plug-and-play, (e) prompt templates designed so guided agents can execute without needing to ask questions, (f) import crumbs as Go module, (g) shoemaking command names mapped 1:1 to autogenic self-* capabilities.
5. Technology Choices: Go, cobra, viper, crumbs module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs), anthropic-sdk-go.
6. Project Structure: cmd/cobbler/, pkg/ (agent, planner, executor, crumbs), internal/ (prompt, config, claude).
7. Implementation Status: phase 01.0 focus is cobbler stitch --docs (self-programming with guided coding agent for documentation).

## Design Decisions
- Cobbler is a partial recursive component composed from guided agents
- Work breakdown makes guided agents effective without iteration
- One-shot dispatch: no agent conversation, complete context upfront
- Agent interface abstracts over guided coding agents: plug-and-play
- Prompt templates designed for guided agents to execute without questions
- Cupboard via Go module import (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs)
- Shoemaking command names mapped 1:1 to autogenic self-* capabilities

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per architecture-format present
- [ ] Clear component hierarchy: guided coding agents composed by partial recursive cobbler
- [ ] Autogenic self-* capabilities mapped to architecture components with formal definitions
- [ ] One-shot dispatch model - guided agents receive complete context, no iteration
- [ ] Work breakdown as mechanism for making guided agents effective
- [ ] Agent interface as plug-and-play boundary over guided coding agents
- [ ] Command set documented with self-* mapping
- [ ] Design decisions numbered with rationale
- [ ] Technology choices table present
- [ ] Project structure directory tree present
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards
- [ ] File saved as docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

title: Write ROADMAP.yaml
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/use-case-format.md (release numbering scheme)

## Files to Create
- docs/ROADMAP.yaml

## Requirements

Write ROADMAP.yaml as a YAML file defining the release schedule and use case status for cobbler.

Commands use shoemaking terms mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities:
- measure (self-orienting): assess state, propose tasks
- stitch (self-programming): execute work via agents
- inspect (self-reflecting): show project state
- mend (self-reflecting): fix tests and lint
- pattern (self-architecting): propose design changes

Releases:
- 00.0: Cross-release milestones (spans multiple releases)
- 01.0: Core stitch (docs) - cobbler stitch --docs working end-to-end
  - Use cases: cupboard connection, doc task execution, agent loop
- 02.0: Core stitch (code) - cobbler stitch --code working
  - Use cases: code task execution, quality gates (test, lint)
- 03.0: Measure - cobbler measure working (replaces make-work.sh)
  - Use cases: project analysis, work proposal, crumb creation
- 04.0: Inspect, mend, and pattern - remaining self-* capabilities
  - Use cases: project state display, test/lint fix loop, design proposals
- 99.0: Unscheduled

Each release entry should include: focus description, list of use cases with status (planned/in-progress/done), and deliverables.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] YAML is valid and parseable
- [ ] All releases listed with focus, use cases, and deliverables
- [ ] Commands use revised names (measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern)
- [ ] Release numbering matches use-case-format convention (NN.N)
- [ ] File saved as docs/ROADMAP.yaml
